com.flyingspaniel.xen
Class Xen

java.lang.Object
  com.flyingspaniel.xen.Xen

public class Xen
extends Object

A simple and sane XML implementation using Java Collections, Generics, and varargs. A Xen ("XML Element Node") roughly corresponds to a Element and a groovy.util.Node.
There are not the 10 other types of nodes and 25 Subinterfaces from Node

  • Attributes are kept in a Map<String,String>
  • text is kept in a single String (always normalized)
  • child Elements (other Xen) are kept in a List<Xen>
If using namespaces, the name of a Xen is always qualified name. The URI is forgotten. e.g. <w:border> <w:border/> has a name of "w:border". There are no Comments, EntityReferences, etc. etc. If you need these don't use Xen. However, all Xens have a field userProperties, which is a Map, which might be useful for small additions.

Combined with Xpath, Xen allows for "XPath-like" selection and movement. Note that this XPath-like syntax is very similar to Groovy's XMLSlurper syntax if you replace "." with a "/". e.g.
Where Groovy might use root.records.car[0].@make
Xen would use root.getAttr("records/car[1]/@make"); // note 1 based offset

Since:

children

public List<Xen> children()
Direct access to all of our children, allocating a new List if needed. Outside callers should use this sparingly and carefully.

Returns:
modifiable List

text

public String text()
Get text from this Xen, and not it's children. Text is always "normalized" (combined into one single String) A loose replacement for org.w3c.dom.Node.getTextContent() and groovy.util.Node.text(), but DOES NOT INCLUDE getText from children

Returns:
never-null, may be empty

getTextContent

public String getTextContent(String delimiter)
Get text from this Xen, plus all children. Breadth first. IMO, pretty worthless... So similar to org.w3c.dom.getTextContent and groovy.util.Node.text().

Parameters:
delimiter - use "" to mimic org.w3c.dom.getTextContent
Returns:
never null

getTextContent

public String getTextContent()
Get text from this Xen, plus all children. Breadth first. IMO, pretty worthless... So similar to org.w3c.dom.getTextContent and groovy.util.Node.text().

Returns:
never null

getText

public String getText(String... path)
Get text from another (single) Xen (and not its children) along an Xpath

Parameters:
path - XPath-like
Returns:
null if that Xen does not exist
Throws:
DOMException - if there are multiple matches

setText

public Xen setText(Object text)
Set text for this element. Text is always "normalized" (combined into one single String) A loose replacement for org.w3c.dom.Node.setTextContent(), but DOES NOT AFFECT children

Returns:
this

putAttributes

public Xen putAttributes(Object... pairs)
Puts (adds or replaces) attributes Use instead of groovy.util.Node.setAttribute(name, value), but allows varargs to support multiple additions

Parameters:
pairs - name/value pairs, must be an even number
Returns:
this

allText

public List<String> allText(String... path)
Finds all elements along an XPath-like path, returning values as Strings

Parameters:
path - XPath-like, last part should start with '@'
Returns:
never null, empty list if none found

attributes

public Map<String,String> attributes()
Direct access to all the Attributes as a modifiable Map. Use with care to implement other functionality in Node. For example 
     void Node.removeAttribute(String name) { attributes().remove(name); }

Returns:
Map

one

public Xen one(String... path)

Parameters:
path - XPath-like, if empty returns this
Returns:
never-null
Throws:
DOMException - if 0 or many matches were found
